suggested_query: Architecture can be seen as an instrumentality that makes thought operable, a device that mediates between the body and the atmosphere. In this sense, architectural design is not just about creating buildings, but about creating the conditions for thought to emerge. The encoding of this instrumentality is the focus of this work, which seeks to develop a computational framework for architectural design that is grounded in the theoretical, cultural, and philosophical dimensions of architectural practice. This framework will be developed through a combination of mathematical, computer scientific, and architectural theoretical methods, and will be tested through the design of a series of computational artifacts that demonstrate the possibilities of this new approach. The artifacts will be developed through a process of iterative prototyping, in which the design of each artifact will be informed by the results of previous experiments, and will be tested through a process of critical reflection and evaluation. Through this process, the work will seek to demonstrate the potential of a computational approach to architectural design that is grounded in the theoretical, cultural, and philosophical dimensions of architectural practice, and that is capable of producing designs that are not only functional and efficient, but also aesthetically pleasing and meaningful.

The instrumentality of the thesis, writing as device, device as writing, follows a lineage of informational instruments that articulate libraries, images, and concepts into operable constellations. The immediate concern is not to predict architecture from data, but to restore architectonic play between media: a space where theory, atmosphere, culture, and association can once again act with design, rather than after it.
